From: Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Hi Ken. How do you feel about Analog Genetic Encoding (AGE)?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=151231063; y=algj_pRcu_zXBc_2lkkvH-4ezD85wp7oZE4kz9FOSrYAww
X-Yahoo-Profile: joeraii

Hi JT,

I developed a very similar GRN encoding for NEAT in my GECCO paper  
last summer:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco07

The preliminary results we obtained were quite promising; the  
indirectly encoded networks not only achieved higher fitness, but did  
so more quickly than the NEAT networks, and furthermore exhibited  
significantly higher evolvability. The test domain was Nothello (a  
variant of Othello).

Overall I think the approach is quite interesting, as GRNs capture a  
lot of the useful aspects of indirect encoding, such as hierarchical  
modularity and weak-linkage, without introducing that much extra  
complexity to the evolutionary model. Unfortunately (to my knowledge)  
there aren't any direct comparisons of hyperNEAT to GRN-based neural  
network encodings, so its still quite a big open question which  
encoding is better for what problem.

-- Joe

On Jan 31, 2008, at 3:58 PM, JT wrote:

> (This is my first post.)
>
> I recently came upon some literatures on Analog Genetic Encoding
> developed by Mattiussi and Floreano. It's interesting but certainly
> not revolutionary. After all it's just a simplified version of
> gene-regulation in real biological system. Some stats shows it is as
> robust as Neat. (Probably not tested against HyperNeat)
>
> Have you had any experience with it?
>
